pt: In Latin the adjective {it}silvaticus{/it}, a derivative of {it}silva{/it}, {ldquo}forest,{rdquo} meant {ldquo}growing or living in the forest.{rdquo} Because forest life is wild, the adjective easily acquired the meaning {ldquo}wild, uncultivated{rdquo} in later Latin as well as in the spoken Latin of the declining Roman Empire. Medieval French inherited {it}silvaticus,{/it} altered to {it}salvaticus,{/it} as {it}salvage{/it} or {it}sauvage{/it}, which was borrowed into Middle English. Medieval French {it}sauvage{/it} retained the source meanings {ldquo}wild, uncultivated (of fruit){rdquo} and {ldquo}untamed (of animals).{rdquo} But it could also be applied to humans, in which case its meanings could range from {ldquo}lacking civilization, barbarous{rdquo} to {ldquo}fierce, cruel.{rdquo} English {it}savage{/it} has had all these senses at some point in its history.

et: Middle English {it}savage{/it} {ldquo}untamed, wild,{rdquo} from early French {it}salvage, savage,{/it} (same meaning), from Latin {it}salvaticus,{/it} an altered form of earlier {it}silvaticus{/it} {ldquo}of the woods, wild,{rdquo} from {it}silva{/it} {ldquo}woods, forest{rdquo}
shortdef: not tamed
very cruel and unrestrained
not cultivated : wild

pt: In the Middle Ages, Germanic people fought and raided other peoples, especially the Slavic peoples to the east. They took a great many captives there and sold them as slaves throughout Europe. The Slavic people were so common as slaves that writers of the time used the Latin word for {ldquo}Slav,{rdquo} {it}Sclavus,{/it} to mean {ldquo}a personal slave.{rdquo} The Latin word became {it}sclave{/it} in Middle English and then {it}slave{/it} in Modern English. Of course slavery and slaves had existed long before the Middle Ages. The ancient Romans used the Latin word {it}servus{/it} for {ldquo}slave.{rdquo} This Latin word is the ancestor of our word {it}servant.{/it} In French, {it}servus{/it} became {it}serf{/it} and was used for a slave who belonged to a piece of land rather than to an individual. {it}Serf{/it} has continued to mean this in both French and English, although serfs themselves no longer exist.

et: Middle English {it}sclave{/it} {ldquo}slave,{rdquo} from early French {it}esclave{/it} (same meaning), derived from Latin {it}Sclavus{/it} {ldquo}Slav{rdquo}
shortdef: a person who is owned by another person and can be sold at the owner's will
a person who has lost self-control and is controlled by something or someone else
a person who performs difficult or boring work : drudge
to work like a slave : drudge
a supervisor of slaves at work
a harsh boss
